verses.heading: Addition D — Esther Approaches the King
verses.text: On the third day, Esther put on splendid royal attire and called upon God, who watches over all and saves.
verses.comment: This addition makes Esther’s hidden reliance explicit: her courage is grounded in prayer. The “third day” continues to carry the biblical sense of decisive turning and deliverance.

verses.text: She was radiant in beauty, yet her heart was frozen with fear. She took two of her maids with her: she leaned gently on one, while the other followed, carrying her train.
verses.comment: The scene highlights both Esther’s dignity and her human weakness. Scripture often shows God working through fragile instruments so that deliverance is clearly His work, not theirs.

verses.text: As she passed through the doors, the king was seated on his royal throne, clothed in garments of majesty, shining with gold and precious stones; his face was fierce with anger.
verses.comment: The king’s “fierce” look underscores the real risk Esther takes. It sets up the theological point of the addition: the heart of the king is not ultimate—God is.

verses.text: Then God changed the king’s spirit to gentleness. He sprang from his throne, took Esther in his arms, and comforted her, saying, 'Take courage; you shall not die.'
verses.comment: This is the theological centerpiece: God can turn rulers’ hearts (Prov. 21:1). What looked like certain wrath becomes unexpected mercy through providence.

verses.text: Esther fainted, and the king supported her and spoke kindly until she regained strength.
verses.comment: Her fainting emphasizes the cost of intercession. Deliverance does not come by denying fear, but by bringing fear into the presence of God and pressing forward in obedience.

verses.text: Then the king lifted the golden scepter and touched her, and asked again what she desired.
verses.comment: The golden scepter remains the sign of acceptance and access. In biblical imagery, it points beyond Persian custom to the mercy by which one draws near and is heard.
